intro: Chrysanthemum myconis f. albidum, commonly known as the white chrysanthemum, is a cultivar characterized by its pale to white flower heads. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is native to East Asia, particularly China. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems and finely divided, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early autumn, producing a soft, fluffy appearance that adds ornamental value to gardens. This variety is prized for its subtle color and is often used in floral arrangements and as a decorative plant.
